column11: Review Text

column8: Relaxing Beach Time Enjoyed by My Clients.
column11: Visited Unawatuna Beach with my clients and enjoyed the lively yet relaxing atmosphere. Clean beach, calm water, great for swimming, and plenty of caf√©s nearby. A nice coastal stop.
Very Good Beach.There are lotof activities to do their.Beautiful beaches,adventurous sports like jetski on beach,coreal watching and divining also there.You can plan your tour with us.
It is an imposition for holidaymakers to stay in Unawatuna. Until early at 4 o'clock drums play and you can't sleep

column8: Nice place to relax after a round trip - as a touri you feel ripped off
column11: We landed here after a tour of Sri Lanka to chill out a bit. The beaches are okay, but not really the hit. If you're lucky, you'll see big water turtles coming to the beach. Here locals sell small plastic bags of seaweed for feeding (1000 rupees) Some TukTuk drivers try to rip you off. Prices are much higher than in Colombo, for example. For 2-4 days it is okay, I would not want to stay here any longer.

The beautiful name of this village and beach is legendary from an Indian merchant who was shipwrecked and settled here. Unawatuna's one-kilometre beach stretched out in an arc. Its main advantage is the absence of a strong wave due to the double reef, which takes the shock load. The beach is good and profile. A gentle descent allows you to swim here with children, as well as people who are unable or poorly swim. That's probably why Unawatuna is popular with the local population, not just the Russians. Although the percentage of Sri Lankans able to swim seemed substantially higher than in India... However, the depths start at 10 or 15 meters. Another advantage of the beach is the availability of sunbeds. They're on display outside beach hotels and restaurants. You just have to grab drinks at the bar and use them all you want. Very convenient and cheap... We're into the Blue bistro restaurant.  Unawatuna is not yet imbued with the spirit of commerce like other resorts, so pressing with extras like boats, bananas, parasailing and so on is practically non-existent. That's a plus to me. You can swim safely... The central part of the beach is more interesting, although most of the vacationers are for some reason in the northern part, although there is not far from the river flow. Not very good smelling, by the way... Maybe it's because there's a lot of restaurants and a few hotels. One last thing. Apart from its main purpose, Unawatuna Beach is good with sunsets. They won't leave even emotionally restrained people indifferent. It's best to see here...

Good afternoon, rested with friends on Unawatuna beach, very nice beach, where you can swim peacefully, without waves, beautiful bay, very many establishments, for every taste and wallet, sun loungers can just be occupied, usually they belong to cafes and restaurants, you can order beer and relax all day. I recommend it for a family vacation.

Gorgeous beach, underdeveloped but with cafes close by.  Not too many beach hassles.  Sea quite wavy but lovely to swim in. Two things spoilt it. Staff in Cormorant Beach cafe claimed we had only paid 1000 rupees when we had paid 2000.  Very hard to prove except a) why only notice several minutes later? b) why did they not chase after us when we left?  I cannot be sure but I think they were trying it on. When leaving we booked a cab with pickme, a hailing app which gets you the fair price not the tourist price.  A tuktuk driver, looking for a customer, told us that pickme would not come here.  I pointed out that we had come this way.  He said it was drop off only.  This seems a little odd.  When our ride did arrive, driver was accosted aggressively and told he wasn't allowed to be in that area. The guy hit the outside of the car violently with us and children inside. It looks like this is a place with some kind of syndicate going on with some dishonest restaurants to boot.  I might suggest giving this place a miss if you don't want to be caught up in that nonsense.
The presence of Russians determines the Mood of the beach and the village. Sadness at its best. Very unfortunate. Don't go there.

column8: Beach was nicer than what we excepted. Great to chill out and relax
column11: We decided to stay here for 6 days at the end of our active time doing things in Sri Lanka. It certainly didn‚Äôt disappoint. The beach was nicer than we expected - nice sand and great restaurants and bars along the beach. Coming from Sydney/Australia we  have stunning beaches but we were surprised how nice Unawatuna is. Lovely place to just chill in sun and relax and July is a great time to come not that many people around and there quiet season

column8: Beautiful beach. Rough seas during the rainy season. No easy swimming.
column11: It's a lovely beach and was reminiscent of our many visits to Goa. Very chill with lots of possibilities to eat on the beach at night. Great sea food. Inexpensive places to stay . Massage available , Scooters to hire. Tuk tuks to hire. Ten minutes to Galle Fort. Just be warned if you like swimming in the sea do not go during the rainy season.the sea is way too rough. We had researched this but never found a definitive answer. Now we have one from the locals. The sea is always too rough during monsoon season. Probably all along the south coast of Sri Lanka. The rains are intermittent and the temperature warm but ok. Just rough sea. East coast better at this time.

I circumnavigated Sri Lanka in three weeks. So as I headed to the coast from Ella, my first stop was Matara. From there to Mirissa and then onto Unawatuna. It was absolutely packed during the day. I was told the area is 93% Russian tourists. Even signs are in Russian. There‚Äôs a tower block hotel on the beach which is so unsightly compared with the landscape. I only stayed two nights before heading up the coast to Hikkadua. I really didn‚Äôt like Unawatuna. Locals try and trick you with over inflated prices. I liked Skinny Toms Delhi for food. My guesthouse was poor and just the general vibe I didn‚Äôt like. You almost get knocked over by the scooters and tuk tuk drivers who meander through the lanes. Awful place, I just wouldn‚Äôt bother wasting your time.
Disappointed about the beach and how dirty it is. The beach and the entire beach area is invaded to tourists, mainly from Russia. Would always recommend the beach in Negombo rather than this one.
soo  amazing   place  in sri lanka and long ago was big historical place. very nice environment .fishing  diving night club  restorans

The place is almost completely taken over by Russian tourists, who, I guess, for cultural reasons, don't acknowledge, smile at, or speak with other tourists. They wear grumpy faces, they grab onto wild giant sea turtles to ride them around. We would not return for this reason. In contrast, the locals all around SriLanka are very friendly, smiling people.

Nice beach, lots of beach bars. You can get the loungers for money, and then you can basically relax well. Bathing is possible, food and drink too. Many posters, maps or posters are in Russian, because our eastern neighbours are in the majority here. They like to drink and bathe in Unawatuna, so it gets loud.

We were hoping for a peaceful holiday, unfortunately you cannot escape the constant loud music on the beach, restaurants. Difficult to get any sleep when there's music pounding out until the early hours. The visitors are nearly 90% Russian. The beach is steep and difficult to access through the strong surf, not recommended for children. The main street is thronged with tourists, Tuk Tuks, scooters and various vehicles. The stench of Carbon Monoxide is sickening. Don't be fooled by the idyllic scenes in blogs, this place is noisy and smelly. AVOID !!

There are many fantastic things to say about this vibrant sea front town. The people are as ever fantastic, but you really have to hunt out top quality food. The beach is crowded and ugly because of it. It is now more of a Russian Blackpool than laid back Sri Lanka

Beach and location are very nice. However, in terms of prices, service and unfriendliness, absolute disaster/naughtiness. Everyone tries to fuck you with completely utopian prices and in the end they are offended. Some want the equivalent of 30 euros for a lounger. Coconut for 5 euros. So who comes here 2-3 days maximum and immediately.

It was a rainy day but still the beach trip was really nice. We can do boating and jet ski in the water. There are a lot of restaurants near the beach for people to enjoy. Views from the beach were amazing.

Unawatuna Beach is truly a slice of paradise on Sri Lanka‚Äôs southern coast! The soft golden sands, fringed by lush palm trees, create a stunning backdrop for relaxation and adventure. The water here is calm and ideal for swimming, making it perfect for families, including those with kids. The clear turquoise waters are also great for snorkeling, offering glimpses of vibrant marine life just a short swim from the shore. The beach vibe is lively yet serene, with plenty of cozy cafes and beachfront restaurants offering delicious local and international cuisine. Watching the sunset from Unawatuna Beach is a magical experience‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss it! For the more adventurous, activities like paddleboarding and diving are available, and the friendly locals make the entire experience even more enjoyable. The cleanliness and maintenance of the beach stood out, and it‚Äôs well-managed, ensuring a safe and pleasant visit. Whether you‚Äôre looking to lounge in the sun, explore the underwater world, or enjoy a quiet moment by the sea, Unawatuna Beach has something for everyone. It‚Äôs a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Sri Lanka!

The beach in the centre of Unawatuna is wonderful.Clean clear water of turquoise color in the sea.The wave is moderate,pleasantly pumping.The sand on the beach is large.The entrance to the sea is not quite gentle,from the shore is fast depth.There are palm trees and lots of greenery

The beach is nice & you can actually swim in the sea without being smashed by waves, however it gets deep very quickly & isn‚Äôt suitable for young children. Not a family oriented place as it appeared most people who went there were for sunbathing, drinking & partying. It was quite crowded when we visited but luckily we were only there a couple of days as it wasn‚Äôt our kind of place at all and yes my politics had a lot to do with my judgement. The Sri Lankans are lovely helpful people who will do what they can to cater for your needs. Nice fish dinners too.

The beach is very average. Yes, you can swim, there are no waves, but it's nothing special. On the beach there are many cafes with sunbeds, just buy a cocktail, beer or something from food, and take a sunbed and a nearby table, it is convenient. Along the beach there is a fairly busy tourist street with shops and restaurants.

I‚Äôm not quite sure what I was expecting at Unawatuna, I‚Äôve read different reviews varying from describing it as a tropical paradise to a tourists hell hole. Either way, it was an incredible disappointment. As my Tuk Tuk meandered its way along the narrow Main Street, all my fears were realised, however it depends what you are looking for. If you want a lively beach front resort that is rammed with tourists, all I might point out, Russian (no problem there depending on your politics), with endless tacky shops and bars and a busy beach, this is your place. You will only hear Russian spoken, all the signs and menus are in Russian which isn‚Äôt anything to particularly detract from the experience, everyone is very well behaved, it‚Äôs just a bit overwhelming. There is a tower block sized hotel that caters solely to this market and floods the town in the evening. I had a little hotel on the outskirts of the town so didn‚Äôt have to deal with the very loud bars and restaurants nearer the centre which might be problematic to some people. My main concern was the pollution. Whilst the main town beach is fairly clean, the beaches at the Dutch watering hole and Jungle beach, are less clean unfortunately. Both beaches have precarious paths to them that are not for the faint hearted, on either beach there are sun beds for a minimal amount and a restaurant. The disheartening thing is that the paths to both beaches is strewn with rubbish, piles and piles of it. I really don‚Äôt understand why someone doesn‚Äôt organise a clean up, it‚Äôs absolutely filthy. The beach and sea at DWP is cleaner than at Jungle Beach which has a lot of rubbish floating in the sea. Not my idea of fun. Having booked to stay a week, my initial horror died down a bit on the second day and because my hotel was quiet and clean decided to,use the place as a base for scootering around but only for 5 days. Hopefully I‚Äôll find some less hectic places down the coast which, if I return will be preferable to Sri Lanka‚Äôs answer to certain resorts in Majorca but then again, it‚Äôs snowing at home and 30 degrees here‚Ä¶.
It's a really amazing beach to spend your leisure time. Beautiful ocean and a quiet, calm place. Lots of restaurants available nearby.
One of the top beach in galle area unawatuna amazing view and best for swimming tourist area most of russians like to visit.

The village itself is cozy with many restaurants and shops. The sea is rough between May and December, so you cannot swim in it. The beach itself is yellowish with some black sand in between. I don't think it's a really nice beach myself. There are many restaurants and terraces along the beach. You will mainly find Russian tourists there, even the information boards in the village are partly in Russian.

Unawatuna beach area could be lovely but we found it to be full of aggressive Russians. The prices are not cheap and we couldn't find a restaurant with decent food. When trying to relax,  we are always pestered by people selling rubbish. Unfortunately we look forward to getting home.

An amazing beach, however I would say that the road that runs along its fridge's is quite busy and whilst we loved it here Weligama and Merissa were more fun... in different ways. I suppose its what you want.... It's all pretty lovely so don't worry
The beach is a long and clean sweep of lovely sand and has many restaurants to eat and drink . The sea is lovely and warm quite wavy at times .

Unawatuna Beach in Sri Lanka is renowned for its picturesque scenery, golden sands, and clear turquoise waters. It's a popular destination for both locals and tourists, offering a range of activities like snorkeling, diving, and surfing. The surrounding area is dotted with cozy cafes and beachfront bars, providing a relaxed atmosphere for visitors to unwind and enjoy the stunning sunset views. However, like many tourist spots, it can get crowded during peak seasons, so it's worth considering the timing of your visit for a more tranquil experience. Overall, Unawatuna Beach is a must-visit for anyone seeking sun, sea, and serenity in Sri Lanka.

We lived near the beach in Aralia. The coastline is long, sand, sand in the water, but there were also stones. The underwater world is not rich, but we saw an octopus and turtles. There are many cafes and a disco along the beach. The beach is public and on weekends there are a lot of local people. The beach is good for swimming, which is rare in Sri Lanka. There are a couple of diving companies.
Nice beach, clean, many cafes and water activities. The sand is pleasant, the entrance to the water is neat, there are waves, but they don‚Äôt ‚Äúspin.‚Äù

We arrived at the rental from the hotel in a tuk-tuk, we had a backpack with us, in it were swimsuits and a wallet with $800 and rupees in small change for travel (the plan was to exchange dollars), we rented a surfboard, we wanted to take turns surfing, but the nice employees were free They offered to lock personal belongings in a wooden box near their service so that we could ride together. We rode for a long time, it got dark and we didn‚Äôt go to the bank. We arrived at the hotel and took out money in a tuk-tuk to put in the safe, it turned out to be $400, but it was a waste. The next day was lost to the police, to no avail. Because they didn‚Äôt count the money right away, they accepted the complaint, not the statement. Be careful! Here is this orange box for things on the left in the photo and the scammers themselves (there is a third one)! And the beach is wonderful, and so is the surfing!

I was really dissapointed by this beach. Coming from Tangalle and Mirissa. I changed hotel and stayed at Dalawella beach instead which was more nice. However this beach was nice at the nights for going out to eat and shop.
It is a nice large beach but absolutely full with tourists, especially Russians, who do not respect anything. There are so much other nicer beaches than going here

Very nice beach, clean and low waves. Dogs and no dirt . Good food at bar " sand beach" perfect praws and very nice mango juice. Find sand, but the water gets deep very fast here. Maybe not very suitable with little children

Steeply sloping beach with a lot of plastic rubbish at one end and a filthy sewer draining into the seawater at the other end. Very busy with a cheaper type of tourism. Avoid, and find a beach elsewhere.

A wonderful beach for swimming, there are rarely big waves here, the entry into the water is smooth at first, then the drop - and then the depth, and on the southern part of the beach this is more pronounced, the beach itself is wide, full of cafes and restaurants, there are also hotels. Along the beach there is a tourist street, which is also full of everything. For those who prefer a relaxing holiday and love to swim, this is the place!

The beach was full of rubbish and dogs doing their business. Such a shame. Avoid ! We travelled all the way from England and whilst  the people of Sri Lanka are wonderful and can‚Äôt do enough for you the situation is a serious problem !

The surfer and local culture has been completely replaced by reckless, mainly Russian, package tourism.  The restaurants try to outdo each other with loud music.  Sometimes until midnight.  You can hardly understand your own words or even a single song.  The quality of the food has fallen significantly and the prices have risen.  Better to avoid.

We had lunch in the Tartaruga Beach Restaurant which is just on the Unawatuna Beach, so enjoyed a walk on the beach! Fantastic beach to enjoying the surroundings while indulging fresh breeze blowing from the Indian Ocean!

Stunning beach. Ideal location for snorkeling and swimming. There are plenty of eateries, cafes, and villas face to the beach. The road's approach is constrained. Available parking spaces are low. Your car can be parked on either side of the street.

Comfortable wide sandy beach, gentle entry into the water, no special shoes needed - sand without stones or anything else. Not bad cafes with low prices and delicious food, as well as amazing pina coladas.
Nice beach to spend a few days of rest with the family. I would recommend as a vacation spot to any family that likes beach, sun and tranquility.
unawatuna beach is located in southern coastal lone of sri lanka. one of the best beaches in the world.

Admittedly, there are dirtier and uglier beaches on this planet (not to say it‚Äôs anything other than bang average). But what absolutely ruins this beach is the vibe of the place‚Ä¶ Most big areas have a Little India or a China Town‚Ä¶ well here lies a Mini Russia. Filled with dodgy locals offering you everything from magic mushrooms to photos with baby monkeys on leashes that they stole from the jungle. We spent half hour on the beach and were approached about 5 or 6 times by people offering all of the above‚Ä¶ and more. This is no longer the tropical paradise as it‚Äôs sold online, it‚Äôs a tainted beauty spot. There is nothing Sri Lankan about Unawatuna beach at all anymore. All character and purity has been ripped from underneath it, such a shame as it‚Äôs not a true reflection on the rest of the stunning country.

An eroded beach, dirty murky water, a canal of raw sewage in one end of the beach, draining into the ocean. Tons of trash. Boaters and jet ski machines operating right next to swimmers with no supervision. Fat women of A Country That Shall Not Be Named screaming at their kids. And no snorkelling, due to the human activity and murky foul water.
Great beach , has changed in recent years due to the big influx of Russians ‚Ä¶ won‚Äôt go back again sadly to say as not many Europeans there now
Rather popular but with a lot of places and perfectly clean water.  Good infrastructure, bars and services in place.

If you go to galle, visit here! Its a 20min drive from galle fort. Beautiful beach compared to galle fort. Visit during sunset! And sign up for one hour boatride! Many good food options. Good place to chill in the evening.

One of the best beaches on earth. Safe clean and lots of marine life.Many good Diving sites close to the beach.Submarine Diving school well located on the beach for this purpose  and PADI instructor Shirly and his crew are well explained on SCUBA Diving.
Great beach offering a large amount of restaurants and bars. Several options for diving and glass bottom boat tours.

Unawatuna Beach is ideal location people who are looking for sun sand and Sea. Very Beautiful and one of Sri Lankas Top and attractive beach. Its safe and November to April season is very good to swim and enjoy the Unawatuna Area. There are few restaurants around there.

The beach itself is good with plenty of options for sun beds, drinks and food. However I can't give 5* to this due to its VISITORS! Summing up the facts: this place is starting to look more like Russia than anything else. Many restaurants have the menu in Sinhalese and Russian with hidden English menus (in some, you even have to ask for it). I wouldn't mind that if it wasn't for the fact that tourists from this specific country are ruining the island. Of course there is good people and bad people everywhere, but I haven't seen other foreigners (from other countries) doing any of the following things: throwing rocks at dogs and laughing, removing corals from the sea into the land or throwing empty bottles of alcohol into the ocean. The behavior of these tourists is just unacceptable. Instead of seeing locals defending their area, we see them supporting this type of stuff/behavior. It's very sad to see this. We know Sri Lanka is in desperate need of tourism, but this type of tourism will destroy beautiful places. They get drunk and ruin your experience with their drunkenness.  I hope the police starts patrolling the beach and making tourists have some respect for the public areas. They also have locals with wild caught monkeys on a leash passing by for pictures on top of you. Animal abuse, bad behavior and habitat destruction to say the least.
Beach is set in a horseshoe format with many bars and restaurants along the way. Sea is calm in most areas good for bathing

A very average beach. Certainly not a white sand beach. Sand quality is just okay, must be a good place for a swim. Quite a lot of beach restaurants and shacks. But none of them worth mentioning. Given a choice between this and Mirissa for lack of time, would choose the latter.

A Sandy beach lined with comfy beach shacks which serve food and drinks and also have accommodation . If you like to stay amongst people then choose a place to stay right here. There are night parties on the beach too. If you are a couple who prefers to have some personal space , chose a hotel a little away from unawatuna and visit this place for meals and shopping . I found the best price for picking up souvenirs in the shops around Unawatuna beach . You can visit during the day or at night and enjoy a meal with a beautiful view and the sound of the waves . Can also take a dip in the ocean here . Since we visited post lock down the crowd wasn‚Äôt much but This seems to be the happening place to be during the peak.

Hay this is an excellent place. This is like my home. where I found a holiday I almost visit there for to have a safe sea swim. Lifeguards are there watching so no issues. Like to experience swimming with different nationals and swimming skills. For novice swimmers, there is a safe area near the temple. This is believed to be a spiritual place, A god who helps novice swimmers to become experienced swimmers  , a god who was a  life rescuer and who died when he tried to save his 4th life at the Tsunami day 2004. I individually believe that faith. If you come here and if you are not swimming, you are against the God ! So come and swim and enjoy ! Snokering is great here, even in shallow water you can do snokering. Please don't put plastics and bear cans to the ocean , please keep this place clean and beautiful , the marine -life depends on it. Bad: Even I put 5/5. There are some bad things to acknowledge. "Male prostitutes" : in this area, you can rarely find the female prostitutes. Almost all prostitutes here are male. They exist as 'beach boys', who are trying to fraud some money from the solo female travelers. Again they are not professional escorts, if you are looking for an escort then go for a professional escort service instead. pimps and thugs are not actually there, but beach boys and amateur tour guides , Stay away from them ! Beach boys are neither escort service providers or tour guides. They are cunning trying to cheat the female solo tourists who are looking for a easy money. You can have a room here for 1000$ a night to less than 10$ per a night. luxury one to very budget one. if you are a foreign traveler and looking for a help, then ask about accommodation from local tourists who visit this area regularly. Budget room ,no A/C, no hot water, but clean around 5$-30$. Middle budget room , with A/C hot water, swimming pool is around 30$-100$, High-end room in a 3 star - 4star hotel will cost over 100$-1000$ per night. Even you don't need to book a room here if you are not staying a night. if you want to swim for a couple of hours here, you can park your car at a nearby hotel , 300LKR car park charges and then take a meal from the bar/restaurant near the temple and you can have free shower after sea swim. Otherwise, it will be 50LKR. not bad. diving is great near the "Aluth gala" area. Discovery will cost around 5000/-LKR. Don't spend beyond that. Romantic activities in the beach: Well, actually it's illegal since this is a public place. But it's quite okay if children and not too much crowded. This is a little bit crowded beach, if you are looking for a less crowded beach, then you may find it near Hikkaduwa. Not a good beach for romantic activities but great for swimming.

Unawatuna beach is in a bay, giving possibility for svimming in not to big wawes. The sand is ok, a bit rough, but sand. The water was when we where there not totally clear, about 2m visibility. But the locals said that it was due to much rain the past days, normally much clearer water. The surrundings was maybe lacking from the covid closedown. We where some of the first guests. But there was many left buildings, garbage and closed hotels/bars. I notised that many signs was both in english and russian‚Ä¶

One of the nicest beaches we visited in sri Lanka.  If you go the far end of the beach you can get into the sea easier, the end near the temple. Sunbeds were free if you bought a drink at most bars or something to eat. Few sellers on beach but if you weren't interested they didnt pester you.

I thought long and hard about if I should stay at Unawatuna beach and thought I would give it a shot. It ended up been the worst beach I stayed at on my trip. We spend one afternoon on it then went to Angel Beach club which is a 7 min tuk tuk drive. Highly recommend Angel as it‚Äôs on a nice beach and has a nice pool with good food and drink, don‚Äôt waste your time with Unawatuna

If you are spending your hard earned money to go on holiday, then do not come to this beach. The place is scruffy, its become a draw for the budget traveller who has little money to spend. Its got groups of people who will buy bottles of vodka from the liqueur store and then sit next to you and order 1 bottle of coke and six empty glasses and spend all night getting drunk. Ladies be aware of the rastsa beach boys, they will be all over you, and watch your drinks, as illegal substances are offered in the the twilight hours. Men be aware, that knives are hidden under the sand around some popular night spots, and if you query a bar bill, then you will be surrounded. The tuk tuks are a rip off, the sand has been imported and is full of broken shells and cigarette buts. Dogs roam freely, and are allowed in the restaurant areas while you are trying to eat your meal. There are so many better areas in Sri Lanka to holiday, give this place a miss.

Nice sandy beach in a bay with sometimes really big waves. Too bad the water is sometimes quite full of rubbish and the beach starts to be full of plastic dirt too. Diving and snorkeling boats cross with high speed the swimming zone and if you are in the way they'd rather whistle that you'd step out of way than slow down itself. A pity for this beautiful beach.

There are lots of bars and restaurants on the beach each with it's own character so it doesn't feel too touristy.During the day most of the restaurants have sun loungers and umbrellas which you can use for the price of a drink.
Best time to visit unawatuna is from Jan-Apr as the waters as calm , many family restaurants are their to enjoy snack
from Jan-Apr is the season to visit unawatuna beach as their are less waves and water calm to getting with family and your ones , many restaurants are their to enjoy shacks

First thing you will notice is that the sand is different. This is because of the horrible tsunami. They did a perfect job to rebuild the beach, but the sand is brought from the ocean and is different than rest of Sri Lanka. The sunset here is amazing.
Superb beach. Clean. Has a lot of activities, but very popular for scuba. There are plenty of good restaurants and shacks right on the beach. And a very good night life.
Busy beach but worth a couple of hours of your time to visit, nice sand and with bars on the beach a place to sit, relax and take in the Indian Ocean
Clean. Has a lot of activities, but very popular for scuba. There are plenty of good restaurants and shacks right on the beach. And a very good night life.

Any trip to Sri Lanka must include Unawatuna Beach. The restauarnts are really plentiful & good. The people are friendly & it's easy to get around with Tuk tuks in abundance. It's a short tuk tuk ride to Galle if you need a bit of sightseeing , history & shopping, but if relaxing is your plan then the beaches are perfect.

The town of  Unawatuna has grown leaps and bounds over the years, the beach the economic driver. It is a nice, sandy beach in which you sink with every step. The stretch opposite my hotel was just for swimming and chilling. The waves were not a big issue. If you stand with your back to the water you have a string of resorts and restaurants. Fresh fish caught offshore can be on your plate every night though it is appreciably higher priced than your standard curry and rice fare. Dinner on the beach is a good experience. Could not get the hotel wifi to upload pix in any reasonable amount of time.

Somewhat unusually I've found that the last dozen reviews sum this place up pretty accuracy. The main beach is over developed but very pleasant. Many restaurants from the fantastic to mediocre. Beach safeish for kids (slopes away quickly with some undertow - don't leave them unsupervised). Plenty of Russians. Ok for a couple of days, but not the real Sri Lanka.
The beach is very safe to relax and have a sea bath. Beach is very free comparing to other locations in Galle. Welle Devalaya also nearby to visit.

Unwatuna beach is a nice bay to walk round at one end is a buddest temple .The beach is lined with bars and restaurants and dive centres.Plenty of boats offering sea excursions and there is jet skis.It is an ideal beach for families and the sea is ideal for snorkelling.

After a long and tired trip in Sri Lanka, we reached to Galle and spend our one day on ƒ±ts popular beach. It has very long and tidy beach and so many local resorts,guesthouses, restaurants. When searching that are for accomadition i was so tired to decide for choosing on right on beach local resorts. They dont like organised and comfort for my familys style. So we decided to stay in Galle Amari and went there especially for the beach. I cant not say that is an amazing beach,sea and resorts side about here but you can come for a lazy day, keep a restaurants sun lounge and feel relax so much.

Very good organised beach. Very long and not so full of people. If you count number of people in the city of Galle, beach is still free. My children had a place for sand plays and for swimming too. There are not so big waves and my 2 years baby can manage them. Near the beach are a lot of hotels and restaurants and bars for avg 300 LKR for a drink like ice tea or beer. I recommend this place for all day.

I have travelled solo round Sri Lanka for the last 3 weeks and thought it would be nice to stop for two nights in Unawantuna beach to relax on way back to airport and also so I could visit Galle. This was not the place for me it is packed full of tourists mostly from Russia and if you like the full on tourist party noisy experience abroad then this is the place for you.  I did find a a great place for dinner at Koha Surf Lounge away from the beach which had a lovely relaxed feel and great food and cocktails try the Gin Basil. So glad only doing short stop here very disappointed as thought it would be much quieter so glad I experienced the real Sri Lanka on my trip which was definitely not here!

Beach nice, clean, large. Lots of restaurants that turn into hunting grounds in the evening. Restaurant staff literally hunts you to eat with them, annoying. Prices do not match the quality, but there are exceptions, you have to look. Nothing special but very pleasant bathing.
the tsunami 15 years ago has changed the landscape dramatically. not the calm beach it used to be.. sigh...! recommend jungle beach about 2km away...

This beach has changed an incredible amount over the past few years, and for the worse. Over populated and over priced, it is basically like how I imagine going to Benidorm in the 80s was. The entire beach is covered in restaurants, and there is not a quiet patch anywhere. Go elsewhere if you want to see the beauty of Sri Lanka and not just a package holiday tourist beach.

Beautiful clean beach. Lots of places to eat and drink. Just be careful to choose a good one as we had a bad experience with slow service at one of them but had a fantastic meal with exceptional service at another.
+ good beach, mostly clean, no stones. + lot of restaurants etc. - deep water. - lot of russian tourists.

This picture postcard location has been over-exploited and literally trashed in some aspects. The basics are all still good, but are tarnished by uncontrolled development of hotels and bars, most shockingly in the case of the multi-storey monstrosity being built at the right hand side; unregulated and therefore extremely dangerous jetski and boat use in the swimming area; noise from beach parties into the early hours, and lack of regular cleaning up of litter and plastic washed up on the shore. All of these nuisances could be prevented and fixed so that the special charm of this lovely spot continues to attract holidaymakers and provide a living for the friendly and laid-back locals.
Beautiful beach with white sand and blue water. Appear like a natural pool and very safe to swim. I would recommend trying snorkeling which we really enjoyed. Lots of places to eat and drink.
Nice, cool, clean atmosphere. Peoples are kind and friendly also the foods are delicious and amazing thank u üôè
You are not in Unawatuna for Swimming and snorkeling.  It is a touristic beach, which is nice , but not tue best at all

Hi, Its golden white sand with blue water paradise of located Galle . Safety sea bath with fully relaxing please with great sea food tasting . Also lots of activities area there spend time mean fully . Thanks .
Nice beach with several bars and restaurants along the shore. Unfortunately too stormy to swim in the sea in August.
Very clean and beautiful beach, many restaurants and shops around, parties at the nights in some hotel on the beach.

People go to beaches for different reasons. My ideal beach has no undertow or current and is deep enough to swim as if you are in a swimming pool. Unawatuna beach ticks those boxes. It is a bay protected by a reef that keeps the dangerous current of the Indian Ocean out. It is actually one of the few beaches in Sri Lanka where you can swim without getting drowned. The safest side is towards the temple. There the water is even suitable for small children. When you swim from the temple towards the main road you feel when the waves get stronger. There will be no undertow, but the waves will be too strong to swim pleasant swimming pool like laps. The downside of the Unawatuna beach is that all the boats are floating in the part that is most suitable for swimming! You will have to swim around these boats or worse inhale the petrol fumes! How can tourist enjoy the freshness of the sea air when the have to inhale stinking petrol! The beach is for Sri Lankan standards wide. Non swimming tourists like to enjoy this beach to lie in the sun or drink cocktails. This beach is however completely artificial. The municipality puts this sand which is different from real beach sand. The sea erodes this sand and then more sand needs to be put to keep the beach. The result is a smaller bay to swim and less clear water due to the eroding sand floating on the water!

We are visiting out of season so we had practically the whole beach to ourselves. Lovely beach to walk along and to jump in the waves. Be careful though as there is a strong current in some places. The beach has beach bars and restaurants and I can see it being a hive of activity in the peak season months.  We opted to have drinks and a snack at The Lucky Tuna and they allowed us to use their sunloungers for free. I would have given the beach a 5, but the number of people offering massages, surfing, diving, clothes, hair braiding, bracelets, sarongs, jewellery, coconuts and stories of the tsunami ..... well with the list of things offered you can see it was not relaxing. They were relentless with the same people asking time and time again. I am always polite, but did finally have to ask them to go away as I was not interested. I know they are desperate for sales, but pestering people deters them...well in my case it does. Beautiful beach though and we enjoyed our day.
It is a really pretty and charming beach, with lots of different food options to select from with a spectacular view. And it is peaceful to just sit and be part of the beach life. :)
I have been to this place 6 times.. I am ready to come back and again...I feel like home here. Strongly recommend to visit this beach))
Nice to sit, relax and enjoy a cocktail or two. Wasn't too busy which was nice. Great restaurants all along the beach.

Great beach, was empty when I went last March/April which I loved. Also so many bars and cafes along it so you're spoiled for choice if you want food, drink or a shisha. The water was nice and warm and I swam 45 minutes to a rocky island (which I enjoyed but wouldn't recommend haha). I sat in one cafe and had a beer and a shisha whilst petting a local stray dog for an hour, a very wholesome experience.

We went to Unawatuna twice during our holiday. The beach was disappearing with the Monsoon season starting and in some spots the loungers were teetering on the edge of a drop! There are lots of lounge areas with prices ranging hugely in price, from a very basic 100slr through to 2500slr but this comes with cool water spritzing, extremely comfortable lounge areas and attentive service. There are safe flagged areas to swim and you can go out to the reef on a glass bottom boat (for a price) there are a few sellers but they are not pushy and will move on with a gentle no thank you! Lots of restaurants and bars along the beach

Unfortunately just like most other beautiful places, it is polluted with plastic bags and waste from near by establishments. In addition to pollution the beach is over crowded . The road to the beach is narrow and not carpeted properly. Surprisingly the water did look blue and clear despite having  a stream polluted water meet the sea near the bathing area. On the bright side, the shallow water reduces the risk of drowning, so it's a safe place for the entire family to bathe (even toddlers) Also the area is safe as there are many tourists and locals. There were some boats offering short sea tours for LKR 1500 (10 min)  and LKR 2500 (20 min)  we paid LKR 200 for parking the car for about 2 hr and LKR to shower after bathing in the sea
Lovely beach which shelves quite dramatically. Lots of chaotic buildings,stalls and bars at rear of beach. Great for young people?

In comparison to other beaches in Sri Lanka, it‚Äôs not great. There‚Äôs little complexity to the beach itself although there are plenty of restaurants on the beach front And it is still a decent beach. There are water sports available but again in comparison not as many. There are also a lot more people trying to sell you things and a lot more dogs than in Mirissa or Hikkaduwa!

unawatuna beach not far from the Galle train station and able to take tuktuk and go. Morning can have breakfast in the unawatuna beach as there are restaurants those who offer nice breakfast there. It is more relaxing beach

Firstly the sand on the main beach is not the powdery white stuff that used to be there.¬† Unfortunately the beach has been extended¬† using sand dredged from the seabed which is more orangy and grittier.¬† Not a huge problem but a bit disappointing and had i read my lonely planet guide i would have been prepared.¬† However we did find lovely powdery white beaches a short tuk tuk ride away at jungle beach and dalawella. Also¬† i was horrified to see a dreadful monolith of a hotel being built at the end of unawatuna beach at least 12 stories high and easily visible from Galle and dalawella. The locals are horrified too... apparently it is a vanity project initiated by the president's son and such a shame as nothing else exceeds the height of a palm tree. And it's planted at the end with the lovely buddha statue so iconic views are ruined

Not been here for a couple of years, and was pleasantly surprised on our return. The beach appeared cleaner than last time., the ambience was good and the water beautiful. We enjoyed a lovely day off, relaxing and soaking up the sun

We only visited for one night. We had heard it was rated in the top 10 in the world! No way can this be and we ave found many nicer ones in SL alone. It is nice enough with a lovely expansive view. But the sand is a little gritty compared to softer sand you can find on other beaches. The beach has a steep shelf into the sea so be careful. There is a wide range of bars and restaurants on the beach; a lot of shisha too. It also had more litter than I have seen elsewhere.
Nothing not to like and it is a lovely beach. It is a bit overdeveloped but still has some charm. there is however more development on the way. For a quieter time try Jungle Beach nearby.
Well it's nice beach,like others in Sri Lanka, we did jet ski here and it was amazing if you want to do some water sport, also the bazaar at back of the beach is also nice, enjoy 3 hours here...
It was clean beach, warm water, and existing beach casinos are serving the sittings, food, and beverages. We saw far playing whales through the Indian ocean.

Wide sandy beach with plenty of sun loungers available in the cafes as long as you buy drinks and food from them. The sea is warm but quite rough with moderate surf. The sea is unsuitable for children or those not confident out of their depth. Initial it shelves gently for a few metres and then suddenly drops steeply as if you are stepping of a ledge into deep water. There are a lot of vendors on the beach who can be quite persistent. Unfortunatly the overall appearance has been spoilt by the construction of a tower block hotel at one end of the beach.

Nice place to swim with less rocks on the beach. At the end of the beach you can enjoy the evening sunset with the sound of waves hitting seashore. Very beautiful beach with variety of activities to choose from like diving, snorkeling, surfing, SUP and so on
not so bad, but we have been on nicer and cleaner beaches in Sri-Lanka with less people. becoming too touristic

The beach was great, with small or none waves, so very good for swimming. Snorkling is possible right by the beach, but the visability is not so good. Also the corals are almost all dead. The beach is with golden sand and it gets deep very quickly. Due to a lot of shells and coralls on the bottom you can use some beach shoes.

Very pleasant especially early morning and late afternoon. Good clean sea with shelf so can get to waist height quickly. Good to swim with light waves. We arrived on a Sunday afternoon which was busy with families. Hotels with restaurants and loungers. May be getting busier as what looks like a large hotel is under construction.

Unawatuna Beach was a welcome respite after three days of hectic activity and driving. A comfortable night's sleep had rejuvenated us and we hit the beach soon after breakfast. It is a nice clean beach with many eating places to suit all pockets. What interested us most was the boating in Indian Ocean. We got some good snaps of the corals.
Good to walk on the beach from one end to the other. Swimming was popular and jet ski, snorkelling and scuba all available. Plenty of beach restaurants and bars.
Lengthy, clean beach with lots of restaurants, sun-loungers, water-sport offerings and shops; but space for everyone. Very few hustlers trying to sell stuff whilst you rest.

There were HUGE waves while we were visiting. Like hardly can walk in the water waves. Lots of tourists on the beach. Not a lot of areas of shade, unless you commit to staying at a restaurant. Nice beach to walk along.
I have sent quite some time here so I might just be a bit bias, but it's a great beach, with good people and atmosphere, a must visit for anyone coming to Sri Lanka

Beautiful beach with plenty of little restaurants and water sports activities. You can find a lot of snorkelling, diving, SUP and surf options, although surfing is more practices in Weligama. There are also a lot of restaurants from which you can choose.

After travelling around Sri Lanka for 2 weeks, it was lovely to finally get our toes into the sand and experience one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs lovely pristine beaches. Our teenage daughters very grateful to be finally at a beach and not seeing another Tea Leaf or Temple!! Sun lounges line the beach with umbrellas, so you can really set yourself up here to enjoy the whole day Beach front. Nice relaxed & chilled out cafes and beach restaurants couple of footsteps  back from the beach. The whole area filled with back packers and a great mix of very interesting people from all walks of life!! We only came here for a few hours but this place definitely on our list of places to stay next visit to SL

Unawatuna beach is beautiful, clean sandy beach, clear water with prefect temperature (in January). There are dozens of shady bars and restaurants along the back of the beach where you can go for lunch and dinner (they move extra tables out onto the sand at night so you can dine on the beach at night). There is a narrow village street that runs from the beach up to the main road that has lots of restaurants, bars, shops etc, which for us was a highlight of the place. If you stay at Calamander Beach Resort they do not tell about this street and if you don‚Äôt know where it is, it is possible that you can stay at Unawatuna beach for a week and not even know that it is there, so make sure you find it! (You can walk through to the village street from some of the other hotels, such as Tartaruga Hotel & restaurant, you walk through the driveway, turn left and right along a few short laneways and then you pop out into the middle of the village!). We loved this village, there are good rooftop bars such as The hideout, and good restaurants such as the Happy Spice, which is down the lane way behind the Pink Elephant (another good restaurant), and the Shifting Sands. We stayed at Calamander Beach Resort and although our rooms were pretty good, the service was underwhelming, meals took far too long so the restaurants were not busy, and we think there were better (and probably better value) places to stay that are also on the beachfront or in/near the village, with a very short walk to the beach. We stayed in 6 different hotels in Sri Lanka and we rated Calamander as the lowest in terms of value for money and service. But we loved Unawatuna both as a beach and a village, thoroughly recommend staying there.
Wide, white sand beach with clear waters.  You can ride 20' on a wave runner for US$40.  Para-gliding is also offered on the beach.
